race.name: Aestari
entries: Aestari Traits

entries.name: Age
entries: Aestari reach maturity at 100 years old and can live beyond 750 years, though few ever reach such an age due to the dangers of their world. Their longevity is not a gift—it is a test of survival.

entries.name: Size
entries: Aestari range from graceful and towering to slim and wiry, standing between 5’8” and 6’6”. Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Speed
entries: Your base walking speed is 30 feet.

entries.name: Vision
entries:
Umbravision
Your eyes, reflecting the dim glow of the city’s skyline, grant you Umbravision up to 60 feet. You perceive the world in shades of gray, but in the right light, your eyes gleam with an unnatural radiance.

entries.name: Poise in Motion
entries: You have proficiency in Persuasion or Stealth (your choice).

entries.name: Trance
entries: You do not sleep. Instead, you enter a four-hour meditative state, remaining conscious while resting.

entries.name: Unshaken Composure
entries: You have advantage on saving throws against being frightened or charmed.

entries.name: Signature Presence
entries: Once per long rest, you can reroll a failed Charisma check.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You know 2 standard languages of your choice

entries.name: Intro
entries: No one knows where the Aestari came from—perhaps not even the Aestari themselves. Their differences are not a matter of history but of form and function. Some are statuesque, with features sharp enough to cut; others are wiry, their eyes restless with calculation. Some move like ghosts, their presence forgotten the moment they leave, while others stand as immovable icons, commanding attention by their very existence.

entries.name: Appearance
entries:
The Aestari are the very embodiment of refinement, their forms sculpted with an almost unnatural precision. Their beauty is undeniable, yet there is something unsettling about their symmetry—something too perfect, too deliberate. Every aspect of their appearance suggests careful design rather than natural evolution.

Their skin tones span a striking spectrum, from porcelain white to deep onyx, often carrying an unnatural smoothness. Some Aestari seem to shimmer faintly under artificial light, their complexions subtly shifting to match their surroundings. Their hair is equally extraordinary, flowing in shades of platinum, jet black, blood-red, or even metallic hues like silver, gold, or copper. It moves as if weightless, resisting the effects of wind and gravity in ways that defy explanation.

The most distinctive feature of the Aestari, however, is their eyes. Reflective like polished glass, their irises capture and refract light in strange ways, often glowing softly in dim environments. In neon-lit cityscapes, their gaze mirrors the filtered lights around them, shifting in color and intensity. Even in darkness, their eyes gleam with an unnatural radiance, making it impossible to ignore their presence.

Their physiques, while varied, always retain an air of elegance. Whether towering and statuesque or lean and wiry, their movements are deliberate—measured, efficient, and impossibly smooth. Some seem to glide rather than walk, their steps unnaturally silent. Others hold themselves with an effortless poise, commanding attention without a single wasted motion.

Though their outward forms radiate perfection, there is an eerie lack of imperfections. No blemishes, no stray hairs, no idle fidgeting. Their expressions are precise, their emotions calculated. Even their breath seems regulated, each inhale and exhale controlled. It is this very flawlessness that makes them unsettling—an uncanny beauty that feels just a little too engineered.

To the untrained eye, the Aestari may seem like an elite class of humans, their presence exuding wealth, power, and control. But look closer, and the differences become clear. Their elegance is not just aesthetic—it is fundamental, woven into the very core of their being. Whether they were shaped by natural evolution or something else entirely remains a mystery, but one thing is certain:

The Aestari are not like the others.

entries.name: Culture & Identity
entries:
The Aestari are a species shaped not by nature, but by control. Every aspect of their existence is carefully maintained, cultivated like a living masterpiece. Where others see adaptation as survival, the Aestari see it as refinement—a means of perfecting themselves in both form and function.

They thrive in environments where power is concentrated, where hierarchy and influence dictate existence. In towering corporate spires, arcane enclaves, and palatial estates, the Aestari flourish as both architects and rulers of society. Their culture is steeped in elitism, built upon generations of meticulous self-improvement, both physically and intellectually.

The Aestari are a species shaped not by nature, but by control. Every aspect of their existence is carefully maintained, cultivated like a living masterpiece. Where others see adaptation as survival, the Aestari see it as refinement—a means of perfecting themselves in both form and function.

They thrive in environments where power is concentrated, where hierarchy and influence dictate existence. In towering corporate spires, arcane enclaves, and palatial estates, the Aestari flourish as both architects and rulers of society. Their culture is steeped in elitism, built upon generations of meticulous self-improvement, both physically and intellectually.

Despite their seeming unity, the Aestari do not form monolithic societies. Instead, they align themselves into syndicates, noble houses, and ideological sects, each refining their own interpretations of perfection. These groups operate like exclusive circles,

shaping the world through influence, commerce, and political maneuvering rather than direct conquest.

Beneath their composed exteriors, however, there lies an unspoken fear—a lingering paranoia that their elegance is a slowly fading illusion. With their reliance on artificial environments and selective breeding, some Aestari whisper of a decline—of something breaking beneath the surface of their curated existence. Yet none dare speak such thoughts aloud, for to do so would be to acknowledge imperfection.

entries.name: Societal Roles
entries:
Among the Aestari, one’s function defines status. The roles they adopt are not merely professions but expressions of identity, meticulously chosen to suit their strengths and ambitions. While outsiders may see them as cold or calculating, the Aestari view their structured society as a work of art—each individual a carefully placed stroke on the canvas of civilization.

Arbiters of Influence: The highest echelon of Aestari society consists of strategists, diplomats, and financiers. They do not govern openly but control the systems that shape reality—economic structures, magical pacts, and political dealings. Their words are law, not by decree, but by the sheer weight of their presence.

Curators of Perfection: Aestari artisans, scholars, and geneticists work tirelessly to refine their species, crafting everything from philosophical treatises on beauty to biological enhancements that sustain their immaculate appearances. To them, the pursuit of mastery is not merely academic—it is sacred.

Ghosts of the Halls: Some Aestari embrace the art of being unseen. These are the spymasters, enforcers, and assassins, those who operate in shadows but never linger in them. Their existence is a contradiction—both invisible and unforgettable, the whisper of a name that cannot be traced.

The Untouched: Among the elite, there exists a sect of Aestari who reject labor entirely. Their role is to exist as paragons, symbols of their species’ supremacy. These figures—whether nobility, figureheads, or deified corporate scions—are untouchable, above the concerns of mortality.

Regardless of their place in the hierarchy, all Aestari share a singular philosophy: to falter is to be forgotten.

entries.name: Naming Conventions
entries:
Aestari names reflect their obsession with elegance, tradition, and control. Their naming conventions are built on symmetry, soft consonants, and flowing syllables. Each name is chosen with intent—whether to convey power, refinement, or an impression of mystique.

Traditional Names:
These names are fluid, carrying a melodic quality that seems purposefully cultivated to linger in the mind. Many Aestari prefer longer, flowing names that sound as if they belong to a lineage of consequence.

Examples: Caelithar, Orisyn, Veythiel, Lysara, Xalendir, Sylthorin, Naevara.
Modern Aestari Names:
In contemporary circles, some Aestari adopt names that blend seamlessly into high society, evoking refinement, charm, and quiet authority. These names often have soft vowels, flowing syllables, and a hint of aristocratic elegance.

Examples: Adrian, Lucien, Sylas, Julian, Victor, Cassian, Evander, Dorian, Alistair, Raphael
For feminine names: Celeste, Liliane, Seraphine, Evelyne, Selene, Vivienne, Ophelia, Isadora, Camilla, Elise
Surnames & House Names:
Over generations, many Aestari surnames have faded, lost to time or deliberately shed as their holders sought to redefine themselves. Some still retain their ancestral house names, while others have adopted sleek, modern surnames that blend effortlessly into contemporary high society.

Common Surnames: Many Aestari have taken on surnames that feel refined but understated, subtly hinting at lineage without the weight of old traditions.
Examples: Voss, Calloway, DaCosta, Alden, Mercer, Durant, Faulkner, Lennox, Sinclair, Everard, Marquette
House Names:
The few Aestari who still claim their noble heritage often retain their house names, which still carry the resonance of old power and deep tradition. These names are often longer, more ornate, and evoke the classical elegance of their culture.

Examples: Val’Kaeron, Orthelias, Sythrin, Vel’Thalor, Elaris, Ael’Veyr, Zarentis, Caelthorne, Lysandral, Vor’Tyrian
Naming Conventions:
Many Aestari use both their modern surname and house name when signing official documents or presenting themselves formally, a nod to both pragmatism and legacy.

Example: Adrian Voss of House Vel’Thalor
Example: Liliane Calloway of House Orthelias

entries.name: Life in the City
entries:
To the people of Concord City, the Aestari are not merely a species—they are an institution, a living testament to power, refinement, and control. Whether as corporate executives, noble elites, or influential strategists, the Aestari shape the city’s destiny from above, never deigning to tread the streets below unless necessity demands it.  

Their presence is most prominent in the upper echelons—towering spires of glass

and gold, private estates fortified by wealth and legacy, boardrooms where decisions shape the fate of entire districts. The influence of an Aestari is rarely seen directly; instead, it is felt in policies, stock markets, and whispered negotiations behind closed doors.  

### Elitism as a Birthright  
The Aestari’s societal structure in Concord City is one of exclusivity. To be born Aestari is to be born above others—a truth they rarely dispute. They dominate the megacorporations, aristocratic circles, and high academia, treating politics as a game of precision, where 

they move the pieces without ever stepping onto the board themselves.  

- **Mega-Corporate Dominance:** Many Aestari own or control the most powerful megacorporations in Concord City, shaping the economy from the highest offices. They are CEOs, financiers, tech moguls, and silent partners, ensuring that wealth flows in the direction they dictate.  

- **Noble Houses of Old:** While nobility is no longer the absolute power it once was, the Aestari houses maintain their legacy through influence rather than force. Their estates still loom over the cityscape, their crests etched into the architecture of history itself.  

- **The Few Lowborn:** Unlike other species, the concept of a lowborn Aestari is nearly nonexistent. Few are ever born outside wealth or influence, and those that are often find themselves absorbed into the system—either through patronage, corporate assimilation, or the unrelenting pressure to excel. A lowborn Aestari who does not rise is an anomaly, and such anomalies tend not to last long.

### The Unseen Game  
Despite their overwhelming influence, the Aestari are rarely seen among the common people. They do not mingle in the streets, nor do they concern themselves with the everyday struggles of the lower classes. To them, Concord City is a grand machine, and they are its architects, not its workers.  

If an Aestari is seen outside the gilded towers or private lounges, it is not by accident. They are there with purpose, whether to negotiate, observe, or eliminate obstacles. To cross an Aestari in Concord City is to risk exile, economic ruin, or worse—and no one ever sees the hand that delivers the blow.  

In Concord City, the Aestari do not rule by decree. They do not need to.  

They rule by the simple, unquestioned fact of their existence.

race.name: Aquilani
entries: Aquilani Traits

entries.name: Age
entries: Aquilani mature at **16 years old** and live up to **100 years**.

entries.name: Size
entries: Aquilani are **robust and powerful**, standing between **5'10" and 6'6"**. Your size is **Medium**.

entries.name: Speed
entries: Your base walking speed is **30 feet**.

entries.name: Vision
entries: You have **Darkvision up to 60 feet**.

entries.name: Sky Mastery
entries: You have **a flying speed of 30 feet** as long as you are **not wearing heavy armor

entries.name: Keen Talons
entries: Your **unarmed strikes deal slashing damage** equal to **1d6 + your Strength modifier**.

entries.name: Eagle Eye
entries: You have **advantage on Perception checks involving sight during daylight**.

entries: The **Aquilani** are **proud, fierce, and honorable**, drawing inspiration from **eagles and falcons**. They excel as **hunters, warriors, and strategists**, valuing **freedom and strength** above all else.

entries.name: Appearance
entries:
- **Sharp, curved beaks**, with **feathers in shades of brown, gold, or white**.  
- **Powerful wings** designed for **swift, efficient flight**.  
- Many **wear light armor, war cloaks, or talon-shaped jewelry**, symbolizing their **martial prowess**.

entries.name: Culture & Identity
entries:
- **Honor-bound warriors**, valuing **discipline, courage, and self-sufficiency**.  
- Live in **high-altitude regions**, building **strongholds on cliffs or mountaintops**.  
- **Some serve as mercenaries, bodyguards, or aerial scouts**, always watching from above.

race.name: Arochi
entries: Arochi Traits

entries.name: Appearance
entries:
Arochi retain **traces of their Pykari ancestry**, but their **lives in the floating fields and trade routes have shaped them differently**.

| **Feature**       | **Description** |
|-------------------|----------------|
| **Skin** | **Fairer tones compared to the Pykari, ranging from wheat-gold to soft peach, with occasional sun-weathered hues.** |
| **Eyes** | **Rounder and clearer than the Pykari, often appearing sharp, bright, and observant. Common colors include amber, steel gray, and sky blue.** |
| **Hair** | **Thinner and leaner than their ancestors, ranging from deep umber to honey brown, often tied in **practical braids** or **loosely woven strands**. |
| **Facial Structure** | **Slightly broader and sturdier than the Pykari, with softer cheekbones and more defined jawlines.** |
| **Posture & Movement** | **Straight-backed, but with a relaxed stance—unhurried, yet efficient in motion.** |
| **Hands & Digits** | **Calloused but dexterous, shaped for both fine mechanical work and heavy agricultural labor.** |

entries.name: Culture & Identity
entries:
- **"We feed the world."** The Arochi are **the primary grain suppliers** to multiple nations, their **rice and derivative products** forming the **backbone of trade and sustenance**.  
- **"A machine should lessen the burden, not replace the worker."** While they **automate as much of their industry as possible**, their **artistry remains essential to the refinement of their crops and goods**.  
- **"Airships carry not just cargo, but legacy."** The greatest Arochi are **navigators and merchants**, ensuring their **goods are traded fairly and without exploitation**.

entries.name: Naming Conventions
entries:
Arochi names are **straightforward, often inspired by the grains, winds, and landscapes they cherish**.

### **First Names**
- **Male:** **Reiko, Haren, Tavren, Oryas, Malkai, Venji**  
- **Female:** **Sahra, Elen, Yune, Rylka, Marei, Tessen**  

### **Surnames**
- **Lineage-Based:** **Ryshar, Goldmere, Velkan, Orenthe, Sunchaff**  
- **Profession-Based:** **Windgrain, Ironseed, Tideharvest, Dawnmiller**

race.name: Canid
entries: Canid Traits

entries.name: Age
entries: Canid reach adulthood by **18 years old** and live up to **90 years**, though **most don’t live quiet lives long enough to see old age**.

entries.name: Size
entries: Canid are **broad, powerful, and deliberate**, standing between **5'10" and 6'8"**. Your size is **Medium**.

entries.name: Vision
entries: Your keen senses grant you **Darkvision up to 60 feet**.

entries.name: Pack Mentality
entries: When **you or an ally within 10 feet** makes an **Intimidation check**, you can **grant advantage once per short rest**.

entries.name: Pack Mentality
entries: When **you or an ally within 10 feet** makes an **Intimidation check**, you can **grant advantage once per short rest**.

entries.name: No Loose Ends
entries: You have **advantage on Insight checks when interrogating someone**, and once per long rest, you can **reroll an Insight check if you suspect deception**.

entries.name: Intro
entries:
The **Canid** are **the muscle behind the throne, the enforcers of order, and the ones who settle scores when words fail**. They **don’t waste time with pleasantries**—they let their **presence, their reputation, and their fists do the talking**.  

Their **bodies are built for endurance, with thick-set frames, heavy hands, and broad shoulders**. Their fur is **short, functional, and practical**, ranging from **earthy browns and sharp grays to deep reds and shadow-black**. Their **eyes don’t wander—they watch, they calculate, they decide.**  

Canid **don’t back down, don’t run from a fight, and don’t let anyone tell them what they are worth**. Some wear **badges**, others wear **brass knuckles**, but either way, they make sure **no one forgets their name**.

race.name: Cindralis
entries: Cindralis Traits

entries.name: Age
entries: Cindralis reach adulthood **slowly**, typically around **30**, and live up to **150 years**.

entries.name: Size
entries: Cindralis are **Medium-sized humanoids**, standing between **4’8” to 5’8”**, **stout yet frail**.

entries.name: Speed
entries: Your base walking speed is **30 feet**.

entries.name: Artisan’s Focus
entries:
Your **mind and hands work in absolute synchronization**.  
- You **gain proficiency in one artisan’s tool of your choice** (Jeweler’s Tools, Smith’s Tools, Clockmaker’s Tools).  
- You have **advantage on checks involving delicate work, engraving, or precise adjustments**.

entries.name: Fine-Tuned Dexterity
entries:
Your **hands, despite your frail frame, are built for work**.  
- Your **hands never shake, even under pressure**, allowing for **perfectly steady movements**.  
- You can **manipulate fragile or intricate mechanisms without risk of fumbling**.

entries.name: Structural Insight
entries:
Your **eye for precision allows you to analyze materials and flaws with ease**.  
- You **always know the weakest point of a structure or mechanical device upon close examination**.  
- You can **identify forgeries, counterfeit gems, or faulty engineering at a glance**.

entries.name: Adaptive Restlessness
entries:
Your **mind does not rest easily**, leading to **erratic bursts of work**.  
- You need **only 4 hours of sleep per day**, instead spending additional hours working on **personal projects or refining skills**.  
- You gain **advantage on saving throws against exhaustion from overwork**.

entries.name: Intro
entries:
The **Cindralis** are a race of **meticulous artisans, jewelers, and master forgers**, descended from the **Delvani** but **radically altered by generations of industrial refinement**. They are the **unsung architects of Cinderhold’s industry**, crafting **weapons, machines, and artifacts of exquisite detail**, their hands shaping the future while their bodies bear the **marks of relentless perfectionism**.

Unlike their **Delvani cousins**, who evolved for **strength and endurance**, the **Cindralis** have grown **stout but physically feeble, their precision-driven expertise eliminating the need for brute force**. Their **minds and hands compensate where their bodies falter**, their craftsmanship rivaling that of the gods—yet never satisfying their own high standards.

entries.name: Appearance
entries:
The **Cindralis** are **immediately recognizable**, their **bodies marked by precision-built evolution**, made to **work, sculpt, and refine rather than fight**.

### **1. Coarse, Metallic-Hued Skin**
- Their **skin is rough, textured, and resistant**, resembling the **surface of cast metal or unpolished stone**.
- Their **hues range from metallic tones**, making them **appear as if sculpted from ore** rather than flesh.
- Common **skin colors**:  
  - **Brass-Tinted Gold** *(rare, often associated with master craftsmen)*  
  - **Oxidized Copper Green** *(a sign of aging or long-term industrial exposure)*  
  - **Deep Burnished Bronze** *(common among Cindralis metallurgists and jewelers)*  
  - **Weathered Pewter or Tarnished Silver** *(unusual but found among older artisans)*  

### **2. Stout Yet Frail Physique**
- They have **compact, stocky bodies**, **appearing durable yet physically weak**.  
- Unlike the **muscular Varnhallians**, the **Cindralis lack physical power**, their **bodies built for precision over strength**.  
- They have **surprisingly weak endurance**, prone to **fatigue if overexerted physically**, but can **work on intricate projects for days without error**.  

### **3. Intricate Bony Protrusions (Subdermal Growths)**
- Their **bones naturally develop subtle ridges, spikes, or horn-like formations**, giving them a **distinct, rugged look**.  
- These **protrusions are never large or exaggerated**, but appear as **small nodules along the forehead, jaw, or wrists**, subtly marking them as **refined craftsmen**.  
- The **more precise and skilled a Cindralis is, the more complex and patterned their bony ridges become**.  

### **4. Diminished Muscle Mass & Elongated Fingers**
- Their **arms and legs are thin, almost delicate**, but their **hands are unnaturally steady and strong**.  
- Their **fingers are unnaturally long and dexterous**, **perfect for precision work, clockwork mechanics, and jewelry-making**.  

### **5. Deep-Set, Monochrome Eyes**
- Their **irises lack distinct pupils**, appearing as **solid, metallic-like pools of color**.  
- This **gives them an otherworldly, unreadable stare**, making them **appear lost in thought even when hyper-focused**.  
- Common **eye colors**: **Smoky Quartz, Brushed Nickel, Molten Bronze, Dull Platinum**.  

### **6. Naturally Slouched Posture & Measured Movements**
- Cindralis **naturally slouch forward**, their **backs slightly curved**, giving them an **absentminded, perpetually engrossed demeanor**.  
- They **move deliberately**, **never wasting a motion**, their **hands always adjusting, tweaking, or fine-tuning something**.  
- They **rarely stand still**, often **tapping, adjusting, or turning objects in their hands even when not working**.

entries.name: Life in the City
entries:
# **Cinderhold – The City of the Unfinished Masterpiece**
*"No work is ever done. No creation is ever perfect. We only refine."*

Cinderhold is **not a city of raging fire—it is a city of methodical creation**, where **the greatest forges, jewelers, and machinists** shape the world with **precise hands and weary minds**. **Here, a flawed masterpiece is worth more than a perfect failure.**

### **Life in Cinderhold**
- **To be Cindralis is to be forever refining.** No creation is ever considered **finished**, only **improved upon**.  
- **Rivalries run deep**—**master artisans hoard their knowledge**, while **apprentices fight for recognition**.  
- **The most respected artisans bear hands covered in scars, burns, and permanent ink stains**, **trophies of their endless craft**.  

### **The Code of Precision**
1. **Perfection is a stagnant lie. Refinement is endless.**  
2. **The hands shape, the mind corrects, the body endures.**  
3. **Creation is a conversation. Mistakes are whispers from the forge.**  
4. **A broken tool is a careless hand. A careless hand is a wasted life.**

race.name: Corvani
entries: Corvani Traits

entries.name: Age
entries: Aestari reach maturity at 100 years old and can live beyond 750 years, though few ever reach such an age due to the dangers of their world. Their longevity is not a gift—it is a test of survival.

race.name: Custodian
entries: Custodian Traits

entries.name: Age
entries: Custodians do **not age in the mortal sense**—instead, as time passes, their **features slowly smooth, their expressions fading, their physical form becoming less defined**. Some have existed for **centuries**, while others **barely remember their first steps**.

entries.name: Size
entries: Custodians are **gaunt, hollowed figures**, standing between **5'10" and 6'8"**. Their bodies are **ashen, mummified, or stretched thin like the last remnants of an echo**. Your size is **Medium**.

entries.name: Speed
entries: Your base walking speed is **30 feet**.

entries.name: Vision
entries: Your unraveling form grants you **Darkvision up to 60 feet**.

entries.name: Warden’s Presence
entries: When you are **within 10 feet of a restrained, cursed, or imprisoned creature**, you can **sense their crimes** as whispered voices in your mind. The voices fade when you leave.

entries.name: Unraveled Endurance
entries: You do not require **food, water, or sleep**. Instead, you must enter a **still, meditative state** for 4 hours, where your form stabilizes against further unraveling.

entries.name: Unraveled Endurance
entries: You do not require **food, water, or sleep**. Instead, you must enter a **still, meditative state** for 4 hours, where your form stabilizes against further unraveling.

entries.name: Gaze of Judgment
entries: Once per long rest, you can **fix your gaze upon a creature**. They must make a **Wisdom saving throw (DC = 8 + your Proficiency Bonus + your Wisdom modifier)** or become **frightened for 1 minute**. If they have **broken an oath or betrayed someone**, they roll with **disadvantage**.

entries.name: Chains of the Forgotten
entries: As an action, you can **summon spectral chains to restrain a creature within 10 feet for 1 minute**. The target must succeed on a **Strength or Dexterity saving throw** to escape. Once used, this ability recharges on a **long rest**.

entries.name: A Whisper of Feeling
entries: You start with **one emotion**, something small, something insignificant—but something **you have never had before**. This emotion **may grow, change, or pull you toward a greater destiny—or it may fade, leaving only absence.**

entries.name: Languages
entries: You know 2 standard languages of your choice

entries.name: Intro
entries:
The **Custodians** are **not born, nor created by gods or mortals**. They are the remnants of those who **walked too far into the Nevermourn**, where reality itself becomes **unstable, shifting, and undefined**. Some souls go too deep. They become **"undone,"** their existence **unraveling** into the fabric of the unknown.  

Yet, from the dissolution of identity, **some reemerge**—not as who they once were, but as **Custodians**. Given **a new purpose they never chose**, they **do not remember their past lives**—only that they **once had a life** before it was erased.  

They are the **wardens of forgotten prisons, the watchers of what must remain sealed, the keepers of chains that must never break.**  

But **some of them change**.  

Custodians **do not feel emotions**—or at least, they **are not supposed to**. Yet, some **begin to awaken**, their unraveling state disrupted by the spark of **something forgotten**. A vague **hunger for warmth**, a **whisper of curiosity**, a **hint of something they know should not be missing**.  

And that is how they **fall**.  

Many never find more than the **minuscule spark** they first awakened. They wander, drawn toward civilization, hoping to understand **what they lost, what they lack, and why their purpose no longer feels absolute.**  

But no matter where they go, **they still carry the burden of their sentence.**

entries.name: Appearance
entries:
- **Gaunt, hollowed features**, with **ashen, mummified, or deathly pale skin**.  
- **Glowing, brand-like sigils** engraved into their flesh, pulsing with **chains of spectral energy**.  
\page
- **Sunken, hollowed eyes** that **flicker like dying embers**—either a dim **blue, red, or gold glow**.  
- **Shadows that do not move naturally**, sometimes **lagging behind their bodies** or stretching toward **prisoners, criminals, or cursed beings**.

entries.name: Culture & Identity
entries:
- **They Do Not Know What They Guard.** They **revere their duty**, **honor the burden placed upon them**, yet they **do not know what is behind the locks they protect**.  
- **A Cult of Purpose.** Their existence is **centered around duty**, forming a **fanatical belief** that their role is **sacred**, despite not knowing **why.**  
- **Some Begin to Feel.** A Custodian is **not meant to feel**. Yet, **some awaken to a fragment of emotion**—a pull toward civilization, a whisper of curiosity, a faint ache of something missing.  
- **The Fear of Falling.** Those who begin to feel **are not spoken of**. They are **not hunted, but they are abandoned**, considered **lost to the unraveling**.

entries.name: Societal Roles
entries:
### **1. Wardens - The Silent Keepers** *(Common Custodians)*
- The **majority** of Custodians, serving as **jailers, guardians, and watchers of unknown prisons**.  
- Many remain in **long-forgotten places**, watching over **seals they do not understand**.  

### **2. Curators - The Keepers of Knowledge** *(The Recorders)*
- Unlike Wardens, **Curators are allowed to ask questions**—but only to record, never to answer.  
- They ensure **the oaths, the rituals, and the duty of Custodians remain unbroken**.  
- Some have **gone missing**, and those who search for them do not return.  

### **3. Deacons - The Unwavering Chains** *(Judges & Enforcers)*
- **If a Custodian begins to feel too much, if they begin to question their duty**, the Deacons **watch them.**  
- If a Custodian **abandons their duty, the Deacons do not bring them back—they erase them.**  

### **4. Overseers - The Hollow Choir** *(The Unmarked Ones)*
- **Their faces are gone. Their voices are silent.**  
- They are **not known to speak**, only to appear **when something has gone terribly wrong**.  
- Some Custodians believe they were **never made**, but **were always there**, waiting for the unraveling to begin.

entries.name: Life in the City
entries:
**In Concord City**, Custodians are **an unsettling presence**, appearing in moments of **great judgment, trials, or executions**.  
- Some **serve as silent enforcers**, ensuring **contracts, oaths, and laws remain unbroken**.  
- **Others have abandoned their duty**, drawn to **civilization, seeking more than the silence of their purpose**—but they are **never free of it.**

entries.name: Age
entries: Humans reach adulthood in their late teens and can live up to 90 years. The Lost Generation (those who first arrived during The Emergence) are now old, while the Emergent Generation (those born afterward) are in their 20s or younger.

entries.name: Size
entries: Humans are varied in build, standing between 5'0" and 6'5". Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Speed
entries: Your base walking speed is 30 feet.

entries.name: Vision
entries: You do not have Darkvision, as humanity’s origins are tied to the daylight, not the dark.

entries.name: Stonebound Endurance
entries: When you make a **Strength, Constitution, or Dexterity saving throw**, you can **reroll the check and take the higher result**. You can use this feature **once per long rest**.

entries.name: Burden of Oaths
entries: You have **advantage on Insight checks to detect lies or false promises**. If someone **swears an oath to you**, you **always know if they break it**, no matter the distance.

entries.name: Foundation of Industry
entries: You have **proficiency in either Athletics or Investigation**, reflecting your **ability to break through barriers or assess structural weaknesses**.

entries.name: Pressurized Form
entries: You are **resistant to force damage** and ignore penalties from **high-pressure environments, including deep water or unstable gravity shifts**.

entries.name: Intro
entries:
The Delvani are Concord City’s foundation—**literally and figuratively**. They work the mines, the forges, the tunnels, and the machines that keep the city running. Their bodies are dense as stone, their hands thick with calluses, and their voices carry the weight of a hundred shifts worked back-to-back. But where others see grit, hardship, and struggle, the Delvani see a reason to laugh, drink, and live loudly.  

To outsiders, they may seem rough and unrefined, but among their own, they are jolly, welcoming, and fiercely loyal. **Hard times are a given—might as well meet them with a joke and a tankard in hand.**  

A Delvani tavern is a sacred place, filled with **singing, friendly bets, and a good-natured shouting match over a card game**. If a Delvani calls you a bastard with a grin, you’ve likely just made a friend. If they call you “sir” in a flat tone, you might be standing on their last nerve.  

They work because they must, but they drink, laugh, and live because the world would be unbearable otherwise.

entries.name: Origin
entries:
The Delvani were shaped by **stone, toil, and the relentless pull of gravity**. They are a people forged in the depths—be it the veins of a mountain or the industrial underbelly of Concord City. While their exact origins are debated, most agree that they descended from an ancient lineage of subterranean dwellers, their bodies adapted over generations to endure **crushing pressure, choking fumes, and the weight of an entire world above them**.  

Their history is one of **survival, migration, and industry**. From the deep tunnels of forgotten civilizations to the steel-forged districts of modern metropolises, the Delvani have always been the hands that built, repaired, and endured. Yet, despite their contributions, they remain undervalued, often seen as mere laborers rather than the **backbone of society**. Some accept this fate with a shrug, while others fight for the recognition they deserve.

entries.name: Appearance
entries:
A Delvani’s body is a **testament to endurance**. Their frames are **short but incredibly dense**, giving them a weight that belies their stature. Their **skin often bears the texture of stone**, reinforced by mineral deposits that shimmer faintly under the right light. Some exhibit **subtle bioluminescent veins**—remnants of an ancestral adaptation to life in the deep dark.  

Facial features tend to be **broad and sturdy**, with heavy brows, thick hair, and hands that tell stories of years spent working the forge, mine, or factory floor. Their **eyes range from ember-red to deep basalt**, reflecting the smoldering heat of their heritage. Some wear elaborate beards or braided hair, a nod to traditions that date back to their earliest enclaves.  

Their clothing is **practical**, reinforced with **leather, metal plates, or insulated fabrics** designed to withstand extreme conditions. Even in formal settings, a Delvani’s attire carries the marks of function over fashion—**heavy boots, protective gloves, and the ever-present scent of oil, smoke, or earth**.

entries.name: Culture & Identity
entries:
If there’s one thing the Delvani hold sacred, it’s **resilience**. To them, **hardship is expected, and the only response is to laugh, drink, and keep pushing forward**.  

Their communities are **tight-knit**, built around **loyalty, shared labor, and the unspoken understanding that no one gets through life alone**. Hospitality is a cornerstone of Delvani culture. A stranger offered a seat at a Delvani hearth is expected to share in food, drink, and conversation—**refusing is seen as an insult**. But loyalty goes both ways. Betray a Delvani, and you will find yourself unwelcome in any of their enclaves.  

Humor is another defining trait, often **dark and self-deprecating**. A Delvani’s way of showing affection is through **insults, boisterous challenges, and rough camaraderie**. If a Delvani isn’t giving you a hard time, they probably don’t like you.  

At the same time, **many Delvani struggle with a deep-rooted frustration**. Despite being the builders and maintainers of the world, they are rarely given authority over what they create. This has led to an **underground movement advocating for worker sovereignty**, with some Delvani factions demanding better conditions, representation, and autonomy.

entries.name: Societal Roles
entries:
The Delvani prefer **endurance over aggression, precision over brute force**. While they are built for resilience, they rarely seek conflict, instead using their strength to endure rather than to dominate.  

Instead of pit fighting or security work, Delvani are more likely to become:  

- **Industrial athletes**, competing in endurance-based sports  
- **Body conditioning specialists**, training others in techniques to withstand extreme conditions  
- **Urban free-runners**, navigating the city’s underground pathways with unmatched efficiency  
- **Smugglers and infrastructure experts**, moving contraband or shutting down oppressive workplaces using structural sabotage  

Even in criminal circles, **Delvani crime tends to be about logistics and infrastructure rather than violence**. They’re the ones who move goods **through forgotten tunnels, maintain illegal safehouses, or sabotage corrupt industry from the inside**.

entries.name: Naming Conventions
entries:
### **Moniker Names**  
Many Delvani pick up **monikers** based on their **physicality, work habits, or role in a crew**:  

- **Sparkshift** – A fixer or machine expert  
- **Tank** – A Delvani who can carry absurd amounts of weight  
- **Spanner** – A troubleshooter, mechanic, or problem solver  
- **Bricks** – Someone known for their stubborn endurance  
- **Axle** – One who keeps things moving, whether in work or community  
- **Deepway** – Someone who knows every underground passage  
- **Rust** – A veteran worker whose experience shows in their wear  
- **Tread** – A courier or someone always on the move  
- **Overtime** – A workaholic  
- **Patch** – A problem solver, often in a literal sense  

### **Occupational Surnames**  
Instead of archaic surnames, **modern Delvani surnames reflect industrial heritage, factory work, and urban survival**:  

- **Holloway** – Descendant of tunnelers, or one who knows underground routes
- **Breakiron** – From a family known for its raw strength in construction work  
- **Rebar** – A name taken from the reinforcing metal rods in construction  
- **Hudson** – A common surname among Delvani in city industries  
- **Grinder** – A family of machinists or metalworkers  
- **Kiln** – A Delvani from a line of metal or ceramics workers  
- **Hearthson** – A name for those who keep community traditions alive  
- **Overlock** – A family name tied to precision work or high-security industries  
- **Tork** – Derived from torque, given to Delvani with mechanical expertise  
- **Bridger** – A name for those known for connection-building or literal bridgework  
- **Gasket** – From a long line of engineers or precision machinists

entries.name: Life in the City
entries:
In Concord City, the Delvani form a **critical yet undervalued** class. They power the city’s industries, maintain its infrastructure, and construct its ever-expanding underground layers. Without them, **Concord would collapse**.  

Yet, despite the struggles, the **Delvani endure**. Because that’s what they do. No matter how much weight the world places on them, they **bear it with laughter, grit, and a raised tankard**.

entries.name: Age
entries: The **Dren do not age as others do**. Their bodies remain strong for **centuries**, their lifespans stretching well beyond **300 years**. Some believe this is due to their time in the Spiral, while others claim it is simply the will of the Dren **to persist**.

entries.name: Size
entries: Dren **stand between 5’6” and 6’8”**, their **frames sturdy, weathered, and shaped by the elements**. Their skin **carries the touch of the Spiral**—some appear **soot-stained, others ember-flecked, and some seem to waver like mirages in the heat**. Your size is **Medium**.

entries.name: Speed
entries: Your base walking speed is **30 feet**.

entries.name: Vision
entries: Your embered eyes grant you **Darkvision up to 60 feet**.

entries.name: Ashen Endurance
entries: You have **resistance to fire and necrotic damage**.

entries.name: Cinder Veil
entries: Once per long rest, as a bonus action, you can **turn into smoke until the start of your next turn**, becoming **intangible and immune to non-magical attacks**.

entries.name: Smoke-Walker
entries: You are **immune to inhaled toxins, poisonous gases, and smoke**, making you invaluable in industrial work and hazardous environments.

entries.name: Keepers of the Ember
entries: You have **advantage on death saving throws**, as if **your body refuses to extinguish**.

entries.name: Intro
entries:
The **Dren** are an **ancient people**, their history stretching back **millennia** to the highest reaches of the **Ashen Spiral**. They were never exiles, nor were they cast down by the will of some greater force. **They moved downward by choice, walking the edges of entropy itself, adapting, enduring, and never breaking.**  

Now, they make their home in **Dreadmere**, the **City of Ash and Smoke**, where their legacy lives on. Unlike those who fear the Spiral’s touch, the **Dren have mastered survival in places that would consume others**. They are **welcoming, wise, and fiercely resilient**, knowing that **community is the only thing that keeps people from falling into the abyss**.  

The world has **burned, broken, and rebuilt itself countless times**—and still, the **Dren remain**.

entries.name: Life in the City
entries:
- The **Dren are not feared, but respected**—they have **seen the end of things and kept moving forward**.  
- In **Dreadmere**, they are **elders, laborers, and masters of fire, metal, and survival**.  
- In **Concord City**, some work as **industrial specialists, fireproof workers, and disaster consultants**, while others serve as **guides to those who fear the Spiral’s pull**.  
- Some **Dren still wander**, believing that **to be Dren is to walk forever, never stopping, never fading**.

entries.name: Intro
entries:
The **Felkin** are the city's **elegant ghosts and silver-tongued deceivers**, slipping through cracks that **most people don’t even see**. They are **quick-witted, sharp-eyed, and always three steps ahead**, whether in a deal, a chase, or a fight. To the untrained eye, they seem **easygoing, even charming**, but those who have been burned by a Felkin before know **never to trust the first impression—or the second**.  

Their fur ranges from **sleek obsidian and cool silver to golden hues and deep auburn**, always well-kept, always intentional. Their **eyes shift like liquid, pupils narrowing and widening not just with light, but with mood and calculation**. A Felkin’s smile is a promise—or a lie, but you won’t know which until it’s too late.  

Some move through high society, **effortlessly navigating smoke-filled clubs and backroom negotiations**. Others lurk in the alleys, **whispering secrets in exchange for something valuable**. But one thing remains true—**if a Felkin wants something, sooner or later, they’ll have it.**

entries.name: Unshaken Resolve
entries: You have advantage on saving throws against fear and mind-altering effects, as your very existence defies reality itself.

entries.name: Residual Instinct
entries: You gain proficiency in one skill of your choice, representing knowledge buried deep in human memory, even if you don’t know where it came from.

entries.name: Unfinished Threads
entries: When making a History or Arcana check, if the topic involves humans, anomalies, or The Emergence, you may reroll the check once per long rest—even if you’ve never studied the subject before.

entries.name: Intro
entries:
It has been 40 years since The Emergence—the day thousands of humans fell from nowhere, screaming into existence in the heart of Concord City. They appeared without warning, dazed, lost, and claiming to come from another world. But no one believed them.  

At first, people thought they were anomalies, or a failed corporate experiment gone wrong. The world gaslighted them into doubt, convincing them that their memories were false, a shared delusion of a people who had simply never existed before.  

Over the years, their past faded into uncertainty. The first generation of humans—The Lost Generation—are now old, weary, and unsure if they ever truly had another home. Some still cling to fragmented memories of places that no one else remembers, while others have given up, convinced that they must have always been here, no matter how much it doesn’t make sense.  

But the Emergent Generation—their children—never had another world. They were born in Concord City, yet they are not treated as part of it. They inherit the changed nature of their parents—the bodies and minds reshaped by whatever force took humanity away and brought them back different.  

They are not anomalies. They are not monsters. But they don’t belong either. And deep down, they know it.

entries.name: Appearance
entries:
At a glance, humans are unremarkable—average height, varied physiques, and no particularly unique features compared to the other species of Concord City. Their skin tones, hair colors, and eye shades span a broad spectrum, but nothing about them suggests a unifying genetic marker beyond basic humanoid traits. However, subtle differences remain, hinting at their anomalous origins.

Those who were part of The Emergence, the Lost Generation, tend to carry an air of unease, their faces lined with exhaustion. Their expressions are often distant, as if they are searching for something they can no longer name. Some exhibit small quirks—fingers twitching unconsciously, eyes shifting slightly out of sync with their reflections, voices carrying a barely perceptible echo in empty rooms.

The Emergent Generation, those born in Concord City, appear more grounded. They do not share the haunted looks of their parents, but many still experience strange phenomena—vivid dreams of places they have never been, an uncanny sense of familiarity with people they have never met, and an instinctive wariness of things they cannot explain.

Though physically indistinguishable from a standard humanoid template, one fact remains certain: humans should not exist, and yet, they do.

entries.name: Culture & Identity
entries:
The initial years following The Emergence were defined by fear and suspicion. Humans were labeled as anomalies, an accident of reality that had no rightful place in the world. Conspiracies swirled—some believed them to be the result of a failed corporate experiment, others thought they were precursors to an impending catastrophe. Whatever the truth, the world agreed on one thing: humans were not supposed to be here.

Over time, however, their presence became an accepted part of Concord City. The initial hostility faded into neglect, and they were gradually absorbed into the lowest rungs of society. The Lost Generation, still clinging to fractured memories, found themselves working menial jobs, scavenging for meaning in a world that had no place for them. Meanwhile, the Emergent Generation, lacking any past but the one given to them, adapted quickly—learning, working, and carving out a future that did not rely on the weight of lost history.

Despite this adaptation, humans remain outsiders. They are tolerated but rarely respected, allowed to exist but never truly welcomed. Many have embraced their outsider status, forming tight-knit communities where the past is whispered about in half-remembered fragments. Others attempt to integrate, striving to climb the social ladder in a city that still sees them as aberrations. And then,
{{pageNumber,auto}}
\page
there are those who question everything—who refuse to accept the world as it is and seek to uncover the truth of what happened forty years ago.

entries.name: Societal Roles
entries:
Humans predominantly occupy the lower and middle classes of Concord City. They are factory workers, clerks, mechanics, and street vendors. Many operate on the fringes of legality, taking jobs that others refuse, surviving in the gaps left by those more privileged.

A few have managed to rise beyond their station, securing positions in law enforcement, academia, and even corporate offices. However, these cases are rare, and their success is often met with quiet resentment from the species that see themselves as the rightful rulers of the city. For every human that ascends, there are a dozen more struggling to prove their worth in a world that has already dismissed them.

Rumors persist of underground human movements—groups dedicated to uncovering the truth of The Emergence, or worse, seeking ways to return to the place they believe they once belonged. Whether these groups pose a genuine threat or are simply the desperate dreams of a displaced people is unclear, but authorities keep a wary eye on any human who asks too many questions.

entries.name: Naming Conventions
entries:
Unlike other species, humans do not have a structured naming system. When they first arrived, they came with the names of their past lives—common, familiar, but stripped of context. Over time, naming conventions have evolved in two directions: 

- Traditional Names: These are the names carried by the Lost Generation, remnants of a past that may or may not have existed. They include names like *Jonathan, Michael, Sarah, Emily, David, Maria, Thomas, and Rachel*.
- Modern Names: The Emergent Generation, born without the burden of lost history, often take names that reflect their new world. These names are shorter, punchier, and sometimes adapted from other cultures. Examples include *Lex, Juno, Cas, Orion, Vex, Mina, Arlo, and Jace*.
- Surnames: The concept of surnames has been largely abandoned among humans. Some retain the last names of their Emergent ancestors, while others adopt new ones based on their professions or affiliations. Some, particularly among the lower class, go without one entirely, existing as singular identities in a city that barely acknowledges them.

entries.name: Life in the City
entries:
To the elite of Concord City, humans are a curiosity at best and a nuisance at worst. The Aestari, in particular, view them with thinly veiled disdain, considering them crude, unsophisticated, and undeserving of their place in society. Other species vary in their opinions, but few extend genuine respect. Humans are tolerated, even utilized, but never truly accepted.

Despite this, humans have begun to carve out their own place in the city's fabric. In the slums, they form close-knit communities where old traditions are passed down and stories of a forgotten world are shared. In the workforce, they are reliable laborers, willing to endure hardship for the promise of a better future. And in the shadows, they move with purpose, seeking answers that no one else dares to ask.

For forty years, humanity has survived in Concord City. But survival is no longer enough. Whether they rise, fall, or uncover the secrets of their existence, one thing is certain:

They are not anomalies. They are not mistakes. They are here—and they are not leaving.

entries.name: Age
entries: Korrak reach adulthood by **15** and live up to **70 years**, though their **hard lives rarely let them reach old age**.

entries.name: Size
entries: Korrak are compact but dense, their bodies built for function rather than beauty. They stand between **5'2" and 5'8"**, though their hunched posture often makes them appear shorter. Your size is **Medium**.

entries.name: Speed
entries: Your base walking speed is 30 feet.

entries.name: Vision
entries: Your industrial-honed senses grant you **Darkvision** up to **60 feet**. You can see in dim light and darkness **as if it were bright light**, but only in **shades of dull red and gray**.

entries.name: **Toxic Resilience
entries: **You have **resistance to poison damage** and **advantage on saving throws against being poisoned** or **affected by inhaled toxins** (such as smoke, gas, or industrial waste).

entries.name: **Scrapyard Instincts
entries: You have **proficiency in either Athletics or Sleight of Hand**.

entries.name: **Urban Climber
entries: You have a **climb speed of 20 feet** and can move across vertical surfaces without using your hands.

entries.name: **Survivor’s Grit
entries: When you roll a **Strength, Dexterity, or Constitution saving throw**, you can **reroll the check and take the higher result**. You can use this feature **once per long rest**.

entries.name: Origin
entries:
*Rough-hewn, stubborn, and built for survival, the Korrak thrive where the city crumbles. They are the last ones standing when the smoke clears.*  

Born from soot and steel, the Korrak have **thick, armored skin and sharp instincts**, making them ideal survivors in the industrial wastelands of Concord City. They evolved within **toxic factories, underground scrapyards, and forgotten tunnels**, adapting to **pollution, scarcity, and endless corporate exploitation**.  

Their **skin resembles cracked asphalt**, their **muscles corded with unnatural density**. **Their fur is short and coarse**, layered in dull hues of **iron, rust, and soot**. Their **clawed feet are built for climbing**, their **eyes reflect dim light like old welding goggles**. They move with the **raw, calculated precision of a creature built for endurance**.  

While corporations treat them as disposable labor, **the Korrak know better**. They are **scavengers, engineers, and enforcers**—the ones who keep the city running even as it tries to grind them down. They have no patience for weakness and **no love for the elven aristocracy that exploits them**.

entries.name: Appearance
entries:
Korraks are built from the debris of industry and survival. Their thick, cracked skin resembles sun-scorched concrete or iron-flecked stone, patterned with the scars of a life lived in the underbelly of society. Their bodies are compact but corded with dense muscle, every movement taut with function. Short bristled fur—like steel wool or scorched fiber—grows in patches across their limbs and spine, in colors ranging from rust-brown to soot-gray.

Their faces are slightly elongated, with ridged cheekbones and blunt features, evoking a blend of reptilian stoicism and industrial design. Their eyes are wide and recessed, built to handle dim, dusty environments—gleaming like molten metal or polished onyx. Some wear scraps of protective gear or tool-belts integrated into their clothing, often not for style but because they’ve never had a reason to remove them.

entries.name: Culture & Identity
entries:
Korraks do not have a centralized homeland. They are a diaspora of survivors, united more by shared hardship than tradition. Their culture is oral, practical, and ritualistic—rooted in hand signs, tool-passing customs, and survival mantras muttered like prayers. Every bolt and scrap carried might have history. Every scar is a story.

Honor is earned through resilience, not rhetoric. You don’t talk about how strong you are. You haul the wreckage, you walk through the smoke, you don’t fall when the building comes down. Korrak respect pragmatism, directness, and those who hold their ground even when everything collapses.

Some clans form underground enclaves, where old welding codes and warning glyphs serve as both language and lineage. Others live alone, traveling from district to district with only their tools and grudges.

entries.name: Societal Roles
entries:
Korraks are often undervalued by Concord City’s elite, but essential to its foundation. They are the workers in impossible conditions, the salvagers of forbidden ruins, the engineers who fix the infrastructure that “nicer” races take for granted.
- Salvage Experts – Their intuitive understanding of wreckage and decay makes them prized as recovery specialists in disaster zones or paranormal breach sites.
- Industrial Enforcers – When corporations want loyalty without finesse, they hire Korraks as frontline brawlers or infrastructure guards.
- Tunnel Scouts – Their climbing ability and resistance to toxins make them ideal for venturing into collapsed zones, sewer layers, or the ash-choked maintenance shafts beneath the city.
- Grudge-Scribes – A rare few Korraks act as historians of the forgotten, keeping track of deaths, betrayals, and the debts society tries to bury.

entries.name: Naming Conventions
entries:
Korrak names are short, guttural, and often incorporate clanking or choking sounds. Many are taken from machine parts, tools, or industrial processes—repurposed as identity.
- Personal Names: Krek, Boln, Vaska, Sharr, Dret, Ferk, Nomra, Kazzik
- Clan Tags (if any): of the Hollow Pipe, Born of Sparks, Ironback, Rust-Eye
- Honor Markers: Some take on new names after major life events, like Smoke-Walker, Steel-Eater, or Weld-Bitten

entries.name: Life in the City
entries:
Korraks do not “live” in Concord City—they survive it. Often relegated to forgotten industrial sectors, condemned housing blocks, or unstable utility caverns, their existence is precarious but fiercely self-sufficient. They form tight working crews, often operating outside official infrastructure, repairing what the city abandons and reclaiming what others call waste.

They avoid the elven aristocracy and corporate towers unless contract-bound, and treat A.S.T.R.A.L. operatives with a blend of wary respect and deep-rooted suspicion. Paranormal zones don’t scare them—they’ve lived their whole lives in unnatural places.

Korraks rarely gather in large numbers unless something catastrophic is happening. When they do, it’s never peaceful—and it’s never forgotten.

entries.name: Appearance
entries: The Naureli are regal, amphibious beings with elongated facial structures reminiscent of seahorses. They are bipedal, with palmed hands, decorative frills along their neck and back, and iridescent scale patterns that shift subtly in different lighting. Their eyes are large and expressive, giving them an almost meditative presence.

entries.name: Culture & Identity
entries: Naureli culture prizes knowledge, commerce, and diplomacy. They maintain ancient trade routes beneath Serevan’s waters and keep vast coral-script archives. They are known to resolve disputes through wit and eloquence rather than force.

entries.name: Societal Roles
entries: Naureli often serve as scholars, archivists, envoys, and merchant princes within Serevan. Their knowledge of both surface and aquatic economies makes them key negotiators in multi-species coalitions.

entries.name: Naming Conventions
entries: Naureli names flow like water: melodic and full of syllables. Surnames are often tied to coral formations or ancestral reefs, such as Thalavir, Orellnara, or Kessaquar.

entries.name: Life in the City
entries: In Concord City, Naureli maintain a respected but somewhat reclusive presence, often centered around aquatic enclaves or institutions of learning. Their unique physiology requires specially humidified environments to thrive long-term.

entries.name: Age
entries: Pykari mature quickly, reaching adulthood by **15 years old**, but they live long for their size—**often surpassing 180 years**. Elders say the fire within them burns slow but never fully fades.

entries.name: Size
entries: Pykari are **incredibly small**, standing between **2'8" and 3'4"** and weighing no more than **40 lbs**. Your size is **Small**.

entries.name: Speed
entries: Your base walking speed is **30 feet**.

entries.name: Vision
entries: Your connection to the **Ashen Spiral** grants you **Darkvision up to 60 feet**. You see the world in **shades of deep red and orange**, as if embers still smolder in the shadows.

entries.name: **Flickering Step
entries: Once per short rest, you can use a **bonus action** to teleport **up to 10 feet** to an unoccupied space you can see. When you do, you leave behind a faint ember glow that lingers for a moment.

entries.name: **Nomadic Adaptability
entries: *You gain **proficiency in two skills** of your choice from **Stealth, Insight, Survival, or Performance**.

entries.name: **Whisper of the Flames
entries: ** You know the **Produce Flame** cantrip. At 3rd level, you can cast **Detect Magic** once per long rest without a spell slot. At 5th level, you can cast **Misty Step** once per long rest. Your spellcasting ability for these spells is **Charisma or Wisdom** (your choice).

entries.name: Intro
entries:
*Small, swift, and bound to the unseen threads of fate, the Pykari move like embers carried by the wind. Their presence is fleeting, their wisdom ancient.*  

Pykari descend from the **Ashen Spiral**, a celestial realm of shifting fire and ephemeral echoes. Some claim they were once **spirits of the Spiral**, their forms woven from ember and motion before they chose to take physical shape.  

Their **skin is deep obsidian black**, absorbing the warmth of the world, while their **thick, curly hair** flows in hues of **dark brown, fiery red, or golden copper**. Their **wide almond-shaped eyes** gleam with hidden insight, always watching, always listening. Their features are sharp yet expressive—**pointed noses, high cheekbones, and lips that curve easily into knowing smiles.**  

Though they have **no single homeland**, Pykari have spread across **both Mycea and Vestigium**, their nomadic nature keeping them ever on the move. They **trust the unseen, follow signs and omens, and believe that the world whispers to those who know how to listen**.

entries.name: Life in the City
entries: Pykari carve out lives in **hidden alleys, underground circuits, and the ever-moving shadows of the city**. They excel as **street performers, smugglers, data-runners, and fortune-tellers**, their nimble hands and sharp instincts making them **essential to both the underworld and the elite**. Many have traded their **fire-dancing for neon-lit hacking**, their **whispered omens** now carried through encrypted networks.

entries.name: Appearance
entries: Rascans are humanoid raccoons with dusky fur, expressive masked eyes, and agile hands. They often wear worn coats, scarves, and layered clothes with hidden compartments. Their tails sway with intent, and their claws are suited for climbing and sleight.

entries.name: Culture & Identity
entries: Living in the margins of society, Rascans value cleverness, adaptability, and loyalty to their chosen crew. Their culture revolves around unspoken alley laws, barter pacts, and encoded graffiti messages passed down in shadows.

entries.name: Societal Roles
entries: Rascans serve as couriers, spies, locksmiths, and information brokers. They are also salvage artists and relic smugglers, delving into forgotten places the city itself has buried.

entries.name: Naming Conventions
entries: Most Rascans go by call-signs or code names: Ashcap, Skitch, Nox, Whisper, or Dritch. True names exist but are used only among trusted circles or in eulogies.

entries.name: Life in the City
entries: In Concord City, Rascans form hidden guilds or operate as lone operators. They are tolerated, sometimes respected, and always watched by those in power. They maintain rooftop dens and sewer enclaves, bound by their own sense of justice.

to 80 years, though many die young in the

entries.name: Intro
entries:
Born of conflict and bred for power, the
Vorraki were shaped not by kingdoms or
bloodlines, but by necessity. Their
bodies are a response to violence, their
culture a reaction to servitude. Once
foot soldiers, bodyguards, and enforcers—
now private security magnates, district
rulers, and the muscle behind every
throne in Concord City.
They were never meant to lead. But in a
city where fear is currency, power
answers to presence.
They’ve outgrown their chains, but
never forgotten the weight. From gang wars
to corporate coups, wherever someone
needs protecting—or eliminating—you’ll
find Vorraki. Their loyalty isn’t bought;
it’s negotiated. Their silence isn’t
passive; it’s calculated. Their brutality
isn’t reckless; it’s refined.

entries.name: Appearance
entries:
Vorraki bodies are built for imposition.
Towering and massive, they radiate
strength, their frames a harmony of bulk
and precision. Skin tones range from
charcoal to deep bronze, often marred by
scars worn like medals. Their muscles are
dense, honed, and reinforced by a rapid-
healing biology that’s kept many alive
through wounds that would fell others.
Their faces are often square and
symmetrical, with stern brows, broad jaws,
and piercing eyes that seem to assess
threats on instinct. Some adorn their
bodies with tattoos, surgical
enhancements, or military iconography, all
telling a story of allegiance, violence,
or loss.
Clothing varies—sleek armored suits for
the elite, streetwear with tactical flair
for enforcers, and old riot gear
retrofitted with private upgrades for
those still in the trenches. Whether in
silk or kevlar, a Vorraki’s style says
one thing: “Don’t test me.
”

entries.name: Culture & Identity
entries:
To be Vorraki is to know restraint and
readiness in equal measure. They are
taught not just how to fight, but when
not to. Their discipline is legendary,
their wrath unforgettable.
Unlike other species that form
traditional family structures, Vorraki
build crews, squads, and units. Loyalty is
earned, not assumed. Bonds are forged in
battle, not blood.
Though often employed as mercenaries,
bodyguards, and enforcers, many are
rising—starting their own firms, ruling
criminal districts, or becoming power
brokers in their own right. And when they
do? They remember who tried to keep them
beneath their boots.
Among their own, Vorraki value:
Discipline over chaos
Tactics over bravado
Unity over legacy
They do not romanticize their origins.
They weaponize them.

entries.name: Societal Roles
entries:
Most Concordians see the Vorraki as
muscle. But the truth is more complex.
They dominate not just physically, but
tactically—understanding urban conflict,
power structures, and enforcement
strategies better than anyone else.
Common roles include:
Private Security Contractors – Armed
and organized, often working for
multiple clients with shifting
allegiances.
District Judges – Ruling entire
neighborhoods with authority enforced
not by law, but by reputation.
Tacticians & Strategists – Designing
responses to insurgency, labor
uprisings, and black-market
interference.
Bodyguard Guild Masters – Providing
elite protection services to monarchs,
CEOs, and even rogue A.S.T.R.A.L.
agents—for the right price.
Some even enter corporate life—not as
subordinates, but as necessary evils—the
unspeaking threat standing behind the
boardroom chair.

entries.name: Life in the City
entries:
Concord City doesn’t work without the
Vorraki. They guard the elites, suppress
the riots, and erase the problems too
messy for diplomacy. No law enforcement
agency functions properly without Vorraki
muscle behind it. No corporation sleeps
soundly unless a Vorraki stands at the
door.
And while the elite keep them close,
they never keep them controlled. Every
deal with a Vorraki comes with a whisper:
“What happens when they stop taking
orders?”

entries.name: Appearance
entries:
The Aestari are the very embodiment of refinement, their forms sculpted with an almost unnatural precision. Their beauty is undeniable, yet there is something unsettling about their symmetry—something too perfect, too deliberate. Every aspect of their appearance suggests careful design rather than natural evolution.

Their skin tones span a striking spectrum, from porcelain white to deep onyx, often carrying an unnatural smoothness. Some Aestari seem to shimmer faintly under artificial light, their complexions subtly shifting to match their surroundings. Their hair is equally extraordinary, flowing in shades of platinum, jet black, blood-red, or even metallic hues like silver, gold, or copper. It moves as if weightless, resisting the effects of wind and gravity in ways that defy explanation.

The most distinctive feature of the Aestari, however, is their eyes. Reflective like polished glass, their irises capture and refract light in strange ways, often glowing softly in dim environments. In neon-lit cityscapes, their gaze mirrors the filtered lights around them, shifting in color and intensity. Even in darkness, their eyes gleam with an unnatural radiance, making it impossible to ignore their presence.

Their physiques, while varied, always retain an air of elegance. Whether towering and statuesque or lean and wiry, their movements are deliberate—measured, efficient, and impossibly smooth. Some seem to glide rather than walk, their steps unnaturally silent. Others hold themselves with an effortless poise, commanding attention without a single wasted motion.

Though their outward forms radiate perfection, there is an eerie lack of imperfections. No blemishes, no stray hairs, no idle fidgeting. Their expressions are precise, their emotions calculated. Even their breath seems regulated, each inhale and exhale controlled. It is this very flawlessness that makes them unsettling—an uncanny beauty that feels just a little too engineered.

To the untrained eye, the Aestari may seem like an elite class of humans, their presence exuding wealth, power, and control. But look closer, and the differences become clear. Their elegance is not just aesthetic—it is fundamental, woven into the very core of their being. Whether they were shaped by natural evolution or something else entirely remains a mystery, but one thing is certain:

The Aestari are not like the others.

entries.name: Culture & Identity
entries:
The Aestari are a species shaped not by nature, but by control. Every aspect of their existence is carefully maintained, cultivated like a living masterpiece. Where others see adaptation as survival, the Aestari see it as refinement—a means of perfecting themselves in both form and function.

They thrive in environments where power is concentrated, where hierarchy and influence dictate existence. In towering corporate spires, arcane enclaves, and palatial estates, the Aestari flourish as both architects and rulers of society. Their culture is steeped in elitism, built upon generations of meticulous self-improvement, both physically and intellectually.

Despite their seeming unity, the Aestari do not form monolithic societies. Instead, they align themselves into syndicates, noble houses, and ideological sects, each refining their own interpretations of perfection. These groups operate like exclusive circles,

The Aestari are a species shaped not by nature, but by control. Every aspect of their existence is carefully maintained, cultivated like a living masterpiece. Where others see adaptation as survival, the Aestari see it as refinement—a means of perfecting themselves in both form and function.

They thrive in environments where power is concentrated, where hierarchy and influence dictate existence. In towering corporate spires, arcane enclaves, and palatial estates, the Aestari flourish as both architects and rulers of society. Their culture is steeped in elitism, built upon generations of meticulous self-improvement, both physically and intellectually.

Despite their seeming unity, the Aestari do not form monolithic societies. Instead, they align themselves into syndicates, noble houses, and ideological sects, each refining their own interpretations of perfection. These groups operate like exclusive circles,

shaping the world through influence, commerce, and political maneuvering rather than direct conquest.

Beneath their composed exteriors, however, there lies an unspoken fear—a lingering paranoia that their elegance is a slowly fading illusion. With their reliance on artificial environments and selective breeding, some Aestari whisper of a decline—of something breaking beneath the surface of their curated existence. Yet none dare speak such thoughts aloud, for to do so would be to acknowledge imperfection.

entries.name: Societal Roles
entries:
Among the Aestari, one’s function defines status. The roles they adopt are not merely professions but expressions of identity, meticulously chosen to suit their strengths and ambitions. While outsiders may see them as cold or calculating, the Aestari view their structured society as a work of art—each individual a carefully placed stroke on the canvas of civilization.

Arbiters of Influence: The highest echelon of Aestari society consists of strategists, diplomats, and financiers. They do not govern openly but control the systems that shape reality—economic structures, magical pacts, and political dealings. Their words are law, not by decree, but by the sheer weight of their presence.

Curators of Perfection: Aestari artisans, scholars, and geneticists work tirelessly to refine their species, crafting everything from philosophical treatises on beauty to biological enhancements that sustain their immaculate appearances. To them, the pursuit of mastery is not merely academic—it is sacred.

Ghosts of the Halls: Some Aestari embrace the art of being unseen. These are the spymasters, enforcers, and assassins, those who operate in shadows but never linger in them. Their existence is a contradiction—both invisible and unforgettable, the whisper of a name that cannot be traced.

The Untouched: Among the elite, there exists a sect of Aestari who reject labor entirely. Their role is to exist as paragons, symbols of their species’ supremacy. These figures—whether nobility, figureheads, or deified corporate scions—are untouchable, above the concerns of mortality.

Regardless of their place in the hierarchy, all Aestari share a singular philosophy: to falter is to be forgotten.

entries.name: Naming Conventions
entries:
Aestari names reflect their obsession with elegance, tradition, and control. Their naming conventions are built on symmetry, soft consonants, and flowing syllables. Each name is chosen with intent—whether to convey power, refinement, or an impression of mystique.

Traditional Names:
These names are fluid, carrying a melodic quality that seems purposefully cultivated to linger in the mind. Many Aestari prefer longer, flowing names that sound as if they belong to a lineage of consequence.

Examples: Caelithar, Orisyn, Veythiel, Lysara, Xalendir, Sylthorin, Naevara.
Modern Aestari Names:
In contemporary circles, some Aestari adopt names that blend seamlessly into high society, evoking refinement, charm, and quiet authority. These names often have soft vowels, flowing syllables, and a hint of aristocratic elegance.

Examples: Adrian, Lucien, Sylas, Julian, Victor, Cassian, Evander, Dorian, Alistair, Raphael
For feminine names: Celeste, Liliane, Seraphine, Evelyne, Selene, Vivienne, Ophelia, Isadora, Camilla, Elise
Surnames & House Names:
Over generations, many Aestari surnames have faded, lost to time or deliberately shed as their holders sought to redefine themselves. Some still retain their ancestral house names, while others have adopted sleek, modern surnames that blend effortlessly into contemporary high society.

Common Surnames: Many Aestari have taken on surnames that feel refined but understated, subtly hinting at lineage without the weight of old traditions.
Examples: Voss, Calloway, DaCosta, Alden, Mercer, Durant, Faulkner, Lennox, Sinclair, Everard, Marquette
House Names:
The few Aestari who still claim their noble heritage often retain their house names, which still carry the resonance of old power and deep tradition. These names are often longer, more ornate, and evoke the classical elegance of their culture.

Examples: Val’Kaeron, Orthelias, Sythrin, Vel’Thalor, Elaris, Ael’Veyr, Zarentis, Caelthorne, Lysandral, Vor’Tyrian
Naming Conventions:
Many Aestari use both their modern surname and house name when signing official documents or presenting themselves formally, a nod to both pragmatism and legacy.

Example: Adrian Voss of House Vel’Thalor
Example: Liliane Calloway of House Orthelias

spell.name: Ashen Breath
entries: You exhale a puff of grayish smoke, which spreads in a small cone before quickly vanishing. Creatures in the area must make a Constitution saving throw or briefly choke on the acrid air. On a failed save, a creature cannot take reactions until the start of its next turn. This effect does not work against creatures that do not need to breathe.

spell.name: Blink and You Missed It
entries:
You momentarily sync out of step with the immediate flow of time, creating a minor delay in perception.
 
Until the start of your next turn:
- Creatures that would notice you must make an Intelligence saving throw or fail to recall any details about your presence until you interact with them directly.
- If you attack or speak, the effect immediately ends for that creature.

spell.name: Cauterize Through Time
entries:
You snap your fingers through folded chronology, sending a burning ripple backward into a wound that never had time to close.
Choose one creature within range. Make a ranged spell attack. On a hit, the target takes 1d6 pyric damage (a combination of radiant and fire), and must succeed on a Constitution saving throw or suffer Disadvantage on their next Concentration check before the end of your next turn.

- 5th level – 2d6 damage
- 11th level – 3d6 damage
- 17th level – 4d6 damage

spell.name: Ceiling Watcher
entries: A barely visible eye- like shape appears on a ceiling, wall, or corner of a room. The illusion remains for the duration but does not actually perceive anything. Creatures unfamiliar with the spell must make a Wisdom (Perception) check to determine that it is not real. If they fail, they instinctively avoid looking at it or standing beneath it.

spell.name: Cinder Veil
entries: A faint shimmer of embers rises around you, warding off the cold. Until the start of your next turn, you ignore the first 5 cold damage you would take. If you are in an area of magical darkness, the veil glows faintly, revealing your silhouette to creatures within 5 feet.

spell.name: Clockless Chess
entries: Summons an enchanted chessboard where the pieces move themselves. Unfortunately, the game always ends in a stalemate.

spell.name: Conjure Mild Inconvenience
entries:
You summon a trivial but deeply irritating inconvenience to plague a creature or small area within range. No damage is dealt, and no serious harm is inflicted—just mild frustration.

Roll a d10 and consult the Chaos Table below to determine the exact annoyance:
